<p>COUNCIL DIRECTIVE<br>of 22 June 1987</p>
<p>amending Directive 80/390/EEC coordinating the requirements for the<br>drawing-up, scruriny and distribution of the listing partieulan to be published<br>for the admission of securities to official stock exchange listing</p>
<p>(87/345/EEC)</p>
<p>THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES,</p>
<p>Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community, and in partieular Article 54 (2)<br>thereof,</p>
<p>Having regard to the proposal from the Commission,</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the European Par-<br>liament ('),</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the Economic and Social<br>Committee (*),</p>
<p>Whereas, on 17 November 1986, the Council adopted<br>Directive 86/566/EEC amending the First Directive of 11<br>May 1960 for the implementation of Article 67 of the<br>Treaty (’); whereas, as a consequence, the number of<br>cross-border applications for admission to listing is likely<br>to inerease ;</p>
<p>Whereas Article 24 of Directive 80/390/EEC (*), as<br>amended by Directive 82/148/EEC (*), provides that,<br>where securities are to be admitted to official listing on<br>stock exchanges in two or more Member States, the<br>competent authorities of such Member States are to<br>cooperate and endeavour to agree a single text for the<br>listing partieulars for use in all the Member States<br>concemed;</p>
<p>Whereas that provision does not result in the full mutual<br>recognition of listing partieulars and it is therefore appro-<br>priate to amend Directive 80/390/EEC so as to achieve<br>that recognition ;</p>
<p>Whereas mutual recognition represents an important step<br>forward in the ereation of the Community’s intemal<br>market;</p>
<p>Whereas, in this connection, it is necessary to specify<br>which authorities are competent to check and approve<br>listing partieulars in the event of simultaneous applica-<br>tions for admission to official listing in two or more<br>Member States;</p>
<p>Whereas mutual recognition can be effeetive only in so<br>far as Directive 80/390/EEC and the Directives to which<br>it refers have been incorporated in the national legislation<br>of the Member State the competent authorities of which<br>approve the listing partieulars;</p>
<p>(•) OJ No C 125, 11. 5. 1987, p. 173.<br>O OJ No C 150, 9. 6. 1987, p. 18.</p>
<p>(’) OJ No L 332, 26. 11. 1986, p. 22.</p>
<p>(*) OJ No L 100, 17. 4. 1980, p. 1.</p>
<p>(9 OJ No L 62. 5. 3. 1982, p. 22.</p>
<p>Whereas the mutual recognition of listing partieulars does<br>not in itself confer a right to admission ;</p>
<p>Whereas it is advisable to provide for the extension, by<br>means of agreements to be conduded by the Community<br>with non-member countries, of the recognition of listing<br>partieulars from those countries on a reciprocal basis;</p>
<p>Whereas provision should be made for a transitional<br>period for the Kingdom of Spain and the Portuguese<br>Republic to take account of the periods accorded to those<br>Member States under Artide 2 (2) of Directive<br>86/566/EEC,</p>
<p>HAS ADOPTED THIS DIRECTIVE:</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>Section IV of Directive 80/390/EEC is replaced by the<br>foliowing Sections and Sections V and VI shall become<br>Sections VIII and IX, respectively:</p>
<p>•SECTION IV</p>
<p>Determinarion of the competent authority</p>
<p>Article 24</p>
<p>Where, for the same securities, applications for admis-<br>sion to official listing on stock exchanges situated or<br>operating in two or more Member States, including<br>the Member State in which the issuer’s registered<br>office is situated, are made simultaneously or within a<br>short interval, listing partieulars shall be drawn up in<br>accordance with the rules laid down in this Directive<br>in the Member State in which the issuer has its regis-<br>tered office and approved by the competent authori-<br>ties of that State; if the issuers registered office is not<br>situated in one of those Member States, the issuer<br>must choose one of those States under the legislation<br>of which the listing partieulars will be drawn up and<br>approved.</p>
<p>SECTION V</p>
<p>Mutual recognition</p>
<p>Article 24a</p>
<p>1. Once approved in accordance with Artide 24,<br>listing partieulars must, subject to any translation, be<br>recognized by the other Member States in which</p>
<p>528</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:113</p>
<p>Bilaga 13</p>
<p>No L 185/82 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Official Journal of the</p>
<p>European Communities &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4. 7. 87</p>
<p>admission to official listing has been applied for,<br>without its being necessary to obtain the approval of<br>the competent authorities of those States and without<br>their being able to require that additional information<br>be ineluded in the listing partieulan. The competent<br>authorities may, however, require that listing particu-<br>lars inelude information specific to the market of the<br>country of admission conceming in partieular the<br>income tax system, the financial organizations<br>retained to act as paying agents for the issuer in that<br>country, and the way in which notices to investors are<br>published.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Listing partieulars approved by the competent<br>authorities within the meaning of Article 24 must be<br>recognized in another Member State in which applica-<br>tion for admission to official listing is made, even if<br>partial exemption or partial derogation has been<br>granted pursuant to this Directive, provided that:</p>
<p>(a) the partial exemption or partial derogation in<br>question is of a type that is recognized in the rules<br>of the other Member State concemed, and</p>
<p>(b) the conditions that justify the partial exemption or<br>partial derogation also exist in the other Member<br>State concemed and that there are no other condi-<br>tions conceming such exemption or derogation<br>which might lead the competent authority in that<br>Member State to refuse them.</p>
<p>Even if the conditions laid down in (a) and (b) are not<br>fulfilled, the Member State concemed may allow its<br>competent authorities to recognize the listing partieu-<br>lars approved by the competent authorities within the<br>meaning of Article 24.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;When approving listing partieulars, the compe-<br>tent authorities within the meaning of Article 24 shall<br>provide the competent authorities of the other<br>Member States in which application for official listing<br>is made with a certificate of approval. If partial<br>exemption or partial derogation has been granted<br>pursuant to this Directive. the certificate shall State<br>that faet and the reasons for it.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;When application for admission to official<br>listing is made, the issuer shall communicate to the<br>competent authorities in each of the other Member<br>States in which it is applying for admission the draft<br>listing partieulars which it intends to use in that State.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States may restrict the application of<br>this Article to listing partieulars of issuers having their<br>registered office in a Member State.</p>
<p>Article 24b</p>
<p>1. Where the securities for which applications for<br>admission to official listing on stock exchanges situ-<br>ated in two or more Member States have been made<br>simultaneously or within a short interval have been<br>the subject of a prospeetus drawn up and approved in<br>accordance with this Directive, at the time of the<br></p>
<p>public offer, by the competent authorities within the<br>meaning of Article 24 in the three months preceding<br>the application for admission in that State, that pros-<br>peetus must, subject to any translation, be recognized<br>as listing partieulars in the other Member States in<br>which application for admission to official listing is<br>made, without its being necessary to obtain the<br>approval of the competent authorities of those<br>Member States and without their being able to require<br>that additional information be ineluded in the listing<br>partieulan. The competent authorities may, however,<br>require that listing partieulars inelude information<br>specific to the market of the country of admission<br>conceming, in partieular, the income tax system, the<br>financial organizations retained to act as paying agents<br>for the issuer in the country of admission and the<br>ways in which notices to investors are published.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Article 24a (2), (3), (4) and (5) shall apply in the<br>eventuality referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Article 23 shall apply to all changes occurring<br>between the time when the content of the prospeetus<br>referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article is adopted<br>and the time when stock exchange dealings begin.</p>
<p>SECTION VI</p>
<p>Cooperation</p>
<p>Article 24 c</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities shall cooperate<br>wherever necessary for the purpose of carrying out<br>their duties and shall exchange any information<br>required for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where an application for admission to official<br>listing conceming securities giving a right to partici-<br>pate in company Capital, either immediately or at the<br>end of the maturity period, is made in one or more<br>Member States other than that in which the registered<br>office of the issuer of the shares to which those securi-<br>ties give entitlement is situated, while that issuers<br>shares have already been admitted to official listing in<br>that Member State, the competent authorities of the<br>Member State of admission may act only after having<br>consulted the competent authorities of the Member<br>State in which the registered office of the issuer of the<br>shares in question is situated.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where an application for admission to official<br>listing is made for securities which have been listed in<br>another Member State less than six months previously,<br>the competent authorities to whom application is<br>made shall contact the competent authorities which<br>have already admitted the securities to official listing<br>and shall, as far as possible, exempt the issuer of those<br>securities from the preparation of r.jw listing partieu-<br>lars, subject to any need for updating, translation or<br>the issue of supplements in accordance with the indi-<br>vidual requirements of the Member State concemed.</p>

<p>Artide 25</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall provide that all persons<br>employed or formerly employed by the competent<br>authorities shall be bound by professional secrecy.<br>This means that any confidential information received<br>in the course of their duties may not be divulged to<br>any person or authority except by virtue of provisions<br>laid down by law.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Paragraph 1 shall not, however, preclude the<br>competent authorities of the various Member States<br>from exchanging information as provided for in this<br>Directive. Information thus exchanged shall be<br>covered by the obligation of professional secrecy to<br>which the persons employed or formerly employed by<br>the competent authorities receiving the information<br>are subject.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Without prejudice to cases covered by criminal<br>law, the competent authorities receiving information<br>pursuant to Article 24c (1) may use it only for the<br>periormance of their duties or in the context of ad*<br>ministrative appeals or legal proceedings relating to<br>such periormance.</p>
<p>SECTION VII</p>
<p>Negotiationa with non-member countries</p>
<p>Artide 25a</p>
<p>The Community may, by means of agreements<br>conduded with one or more non-member countries<br></p>
<p>pursuant to the Treaty, recognize listing partieulars<br>drawn up and checked, in accordance with the ruies<br>of the non-member country or countries, as meeting<br>the requirements of this Directive, subject to recipro-<br>city, provided that the ruies concemed give investors<br>protection equivalent to that afforded by this Direc-<br>tive, even if those ruies differ from the provisions of<br>this Directive.’</p>
<p>Artide 2</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall take the measures necessary for<br>them to comply with this Directive by 1 January 1990.<br>They shall forthwith inform the Commission thereof.<br>However, for the Kingdom of Spain the date 1 January<br>1990 shall be replaced by 1 January 1991 and for the<br>Portuguese Republic by 1 January 1992.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall communicate to the Commis-<br>sion the texts of the main laws, regulations and adminis-<br>trative provisions which they adopt in the field covered by<br>this Directive.</p>
<p>Artide 3</p>
<p>This Directive is addressed to the Member States.</p>
<p>Done at Luxembourg, 22 June 1987.</p>
<p>For the Council</p>

<h2>COUNCIL</h2>
<p>COUNCIL DIRECTIVE<br>of 15 February 1982<br>on information to bc published on a regular basis by companies the shares of<br>which have been admitted to official stock-exchange listing</p>
<p>(82/121/EEQ</p>
<p>THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN</p>
<p>COMMUNITIES,</p>
<p>Having regard to the Treaty esublishing the European<br>Economic Community, and in partieular Artides 54<br>(3) (g) and 100 thereof.</p>
<p>Having regard to the proposal from the Commis-<br>sion ('),</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the European<br>Parliament</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the Economic and<br>Social Committee C<sup>1</sup>),</p>
<p>Whereas Council D<sup>;</sup>rective 80/390/EEC of 17 March<br>1980 coordinating the requirements for the drawing<br>up, scrutiny and distribution of the listing partieulars<br>to be published for the admission of secunties to offi-<br>cial stock-exchange listing (*) seeks to ensure improved<br>protection of investors and a greater degree of equiva-<br>lence in the protection provided, by coordinating<br>requirements as to the information to be published at<br>the time of admission ;</p>
<p>Whereas, in the case of securities admitted to official<br>stock-exchange listing. the protection of investors<br>requires that the latter be supplied with appropriate<br>regular information throughout the entire period<br>during which the securities are listed; whereas coordi-</p>
<p>(’) OJ No C 29. I. 2. 1979. p. 5 and OJ No C 210. 16. 8.<br>1980. p. 5.</p>
<p>(<sup>J</sup>) OJ No C 85. 8. 4. 1980. p. 69.</p>
<p>(’) OJ No C 53. 3. 3. 1980. p. 54.</p>
<p>(•) OJ No L 100. 17. 4. 1980. p. 1.<br></p>
<p>nation of requirements for this regular information has<br>similar objectives to those envisaged for the listing<br>partieulars, namely to improve such protection and to<br>make it more equivalent, to facilitate the listing of<br>these securities on more than one stock exchange in<br>the Community, and in so doing to contribute towards<br>the establishment of a genuine Community capiul<br>market by permitting a fuller interpenetration of<br>securities markets;</p>
<p>Whereas, under Council Directive 79/279/EEC of 5<br>March 1979 coordinating the conditions for the admis-<br>sion of securities to official stock-exchange listing<br>listed companies must as soon as possible make avail-<br>able to investors their annual accounts and report<br>giving information on the company for the whole of<br>the financial year; whereas the fourth Directive<br>78/660/EEC (*) has coordinated the laws, regulations<br>and administrative provisions of the Member Sutes<br>conceming the annual accounts of certain types of<br>companies;</p>
<p>Whereas companies should also, at least once during<br>each financial year, make available to investors reports<br>on their activities; whereas this Directive can, conse-<br>quently, be confined to coordinating the content and<br>distribution of a single report covering the first six<br>months of the financial year;</p>
<p>Whereas, however. in the case of ordinary debentures,<br>because of the rights they confer on their holders, the<br>protection of investors by means of the publication of<br>a half-yearly report is not essential; whereas, by virtue</p>
<p>(*) OJ No L 66. 16. 3. 1979. p. 21.<br>(•) OJ No L 222. 14. 8. 1978. p. II.</p>

<p>of- Directive 79/279/EEC, convertible or exchangeable<br>debentures and debentures with wamnu may be<br>admitted to official listing only if the related shares are<br>already listed on the same stock exchange or on<br>another reguiated, regularly operating, recognized open<br>market or are so admitted simultaneously; whereas the<br>Member States may derogate from this principle only<br>if their competent authorities are satisfied that holden<br>have at their disposal all the information necessary to<br>form an opinion conceming the value of the shares to<br>which these debentures reläte; whereas, consequently,<br>regular information needs to be coordinated only for<br>companies whose shares are admitted to official stock-<br>exchange listing;</p>
<p>Whereas the half-yearly report must enable investon<br>to make an informed appraisal of the general develop-<br>ment of the company s activities during the period<br>covered by the report; whereas, however, this report<br>need contain only the essential deuils on the financial<br>position and general progress of the business of the<br>company in question ;</p>
<p>Whereas, in order to uke account of diffieulties<br>resuiting from the current State of laws in certain<br>Member States, companies may be allowed a longer<br>period to implement the provisions of this Directive<br>than that laid down for the adapution of national<br>laws;</p>
<p>Whereas, so as to ensure the effeetive protection of<br>investors and the proper operation of stock exchanges,<br>the ruies relating to regular information to be<br>published by companies, the shares of which are<br>admitted to official stock-exchange listing within the<br>Community, should apply not only to companies from<br>Member States, but also to companies from non-<br>member countries</p>
<p>HAS ADOPTED THIS DIRECTIVE:</p>
<p>SECTION I</p>
<p>General provisions and seope</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;This Directive shall apply to companies the<br>shares of which are admitted to official listing on a<br>stock exchange situated or operating in a Member<br>State, whether the admission is of the shares them-<br>selves or of certificates representing them and whether<br>such admission precedes or follows the date on which<br>this Directive enters into force.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;This Directive shall not, however. apply to invest-<br>ment companies other than those of the closed-end<br>type.</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Directive ‘investment com-<br>panies other than those of the closed-end type’ shall<br>mean investment companies :</p>
<p>— the object of which is the collective investment of<br>capiul provided by the public, and which operate<br>on the principle of risk spreading, and</p>
<p>— the shares of which are, at the holders’ request,<br>repurchased or redeemed, directly or indirectly, out<br>of those companies* assets. Action uken by such<br>companies to ensure that the stock-exchange value<br>of their shares does not significantly vary from<br>their net asset value shall be regarded as equivalent<br>to such repurchase or redemption.</p>
<p>3. The Member Sutes may exelude central banks<br>from the seope of this Directive.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>The Member Sutes shall ensure that the companies<br>publish half-yearly reports on their activities and<br>profits and losses during the first six months of each<br>financial year.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>The Member States may subject companies to obliga-<br>tions more stringent than those provided for by this<br>Directive or to additional obligations, provided that<br>they apply generally to all companies or to all<br>companies of a given class.</p>
<p>SECTION II</p>
<p>Publication and contents<br>of the half-yearly report</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The half-yearly report shall be published within<br>four months of the end of the relevant six-month<br>period.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;In exceptional, duly subsuntiated cases, the<br>competent authorities shall be permitted to extend the<br>time limit for publication.</p>
<p>Article 3</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The half-yearly report shall consist of figures and<br>an explanatory sutement relating to the company’s<br>activities and profits and losses during the relevant<br>six-month period.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The figures, presented in uble form, shall indi-<br>cate at least:</p>
<p>— the net tumover, and</p>
<p>— the profit or loss before or after deduetion of Ux.</p>
<p>These terms shall havr the same meanings as in the<br>Council Directives on . &gt;mpany accounts.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;The Member Sutes may allow the competent<br>authorities to authorize companies, exceptionally and<br>on a case-by-case basis, to supply estimated figures for<br>profits and losses, provided that the shares of each<br>such company are listed officially in only one Member</p>
<p>534</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:113</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>No L 48/28</p>
<p>Official Journal of the European Communities</p>
<p>20. 2. 82</p>
<p>State. The use of this procedure must be indicated by<br>the company in its report and must not mislead<br>investors.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where the company has paid or proposes to pay<br>an interim dividend, the figures must indicate the<br>profit or loss after tax for the six-month period and<br>the interim dividend paid or proposed.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;Against each figure there must be shown the<br>figure for the corresponding period in the preceding<br>financial year.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;The explanatory statement must inelude any<br>significant information enabling investors to make an<br>informed assessment of the trend of the companys<br>activities and profits or losses together with an indica-<br>tion of any special faetor which has influenced those<br>activities and those profits or losses during the period<br>in question, and enable a companson to be made with<br>the corresponding period of the preceding financial<br>year.</p>
<p>It must also, as far as possible, refer to the company’s<br>likely future development in the current financial year.</p>
<p>7. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where the figures provided for in paragraph 2<br>are unsuited to the company’s activities, the competent<br>authorities shall ensure that appropriate adjustment!<br>are made.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>Where a company publishes Consolidated accounts it<br>may publish its half-yearly report in either Consoli-<br>dated or unconsolidated form. However, the Member<br>States may allow the competent authorities, where the<br>latter consider that the form not adopted would have<br>contained additional material information, to require<br>the company to publish such information.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The half-yearly report must be published in the<br>Member State or Member States where the shares are<br>admitted to official listing by insertion in one or more<br>newspapers distributed throughout the State or widely<br>distributed therein or in the national gazette. or shall<br>be made available to the public either in writing in<br>places indicated by announcement to be published in<br>one or more newspapers distributed throughout the<br>State or widely distributed therein, or by other equiva-<br>lent means approved by the competent authorities.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;A half-yearly report must be drawn up in the<br>official language or languages or in one of the official<br>languages or in another language, provided that, in the<br>Member State concemed, such official language or<br>languages or such other language are customary in the<br></p>
<p>sphere of finance and are accepted by the competent<br>authorities.</p>
<p>3. The company shall send a copy of its half-yearly<br>report simultaneously to the competent authorities of<br>each Member State in which its shares are admitted to<br>official listing. It shall do so not later than the time<br>when the half-yearly report is published for the first<br>time in a Member State.</p>
<p>Article 8</p>
<p>Where the accounting information has been audited<br>by the official auditor of the companys accounts, that<br>auditor*! report and any qualifications he may have<br>shall be reproduced in full.</p>
<p>SECTION III</p>
<p>Powers of the competent authorities</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall appoint one or more compe-<br>tent authorities and shall notify the Commission of<br>the appointment of such authorities, giving details of<br>any division of powers among them. Member States<br>shall also ensure that this Directive is applied.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The Member States shall ensure that the compe-<br>tent authorities have the necessary powers to carry out<br>their tasL</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where partieular requirements of this Directive<br>are unsuited to a company's activities or circum-<br>stances, the competent authorities shall ensure that<br>suitable adaptations are made to such requirements.</p>
<p>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities may authorize the<br>omission from the half-yearly report of certain infor-<br>mation provided for in this Directive if they consider<br>that disclosure of such information would be contrary<br>to the public interest or seriously detrimental to the<br>company, provided that, in the latter case, such omis-<br>sion would not be likely to mislead the public with<br>regard to faets and circumstances knowledge of which<br>is essential for the assessment of the shares in ques-<br>tion.</p>
<p>The company or its representatives shall be respon-<br>sible for the correctness and relevance of the faets on<br>which any application for such exemption is based.</p>
<p>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;Paragraphs 3 and 4 shall also apply to the more<br>stringent or additionai obligations imposed pursuant to<br>Article 3.</p>
<p>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;If a company governed by the law of a non-<br>member country publishes a half-yearly report in a<br>non-member country, the competent authorities may<br>authorize it to publish that report instead of the half-<br>yearly report provided for in this Directive, provided</p>
<p>535</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:113</p>
<p>Bilaga 15</p>
<p>20. 2. 82</p>
<p>Official Journal of the European Communities</p>
<p>No L 48/29</p>
<p>that the information given is equivalent to that which<br>would resuit from the application of this Directive.</p>
<p>7. This Directive shall not affect the competent<br>authorities’ liability, which shall continue to be<br>governed solely by national law.</p>
<p>SECTION IV</p>
<p>Cooperarion between Member States</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities shall cooperate<br>whenever necessary for the purpose of carrying out<br>their duties and shall exchange any information<br>required for that purpose.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where a half-yearly report has to be published in<br>more than one Member State, the competent authori-<br>ties of these Member States shall, by way of derogation<br>from Article 3, use their best endeavours to accept as a<br>single text the text which meets the requirements of<br>the Member State in which the company s shares were<br>admitted to official listing for the first time or the text<br>which most closely approximates to that text. In cases<br>of simultaneous admission to official listing on two or<br>more stock exchanges situated or operating in differ-<br>ent Member States, the competent authorities of the<br>Member States concemed shall use their best endeav-<br>oun to accept as a single text the text of the report<br>which meets the requirements of the Member State in<br>which the companys head office is situated; if the<br>company*s head office is situated in a non-member<br>country, the competent authorities of the Member<br>States concemed shall use their best endeavours to<br>accept a single version of the report.</p>
<p>SECTION V</p>
<p>Contact Committee</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>I. The Contact Committee set up by Article 20 of<br>Directive 79/279/EEC shall also have as its function :</p>
<p>(a) without prejudice to Artides 169 and 170 of the<br>Treaty to facilitate the harmonized implementation<br>of this Directive through regular consultations on<br>any pr»ctical problems arising from its application<br>on which exchanges of views are deemed useful;</p>
<p>(b) to facilitate consultation between the Member<br>States on the more stringent or additionai obliga-<br>tions which they may impose pursuant to Article 3<br>with a view to the ultimate convergence of obliga-<br>tions imposed in all Member Sutes, in accordance<br>with Article 54 (3) (g) of the Treaty;</p>
<p>(c) to advise the Commission, if necessary, on any<br>additions or amendments to be made to this Direc-<br>tive; in partieular, the Committee shall consider<br>the possible modification of Artides 3 and 5 in the<br>light of progress towards the convergence of obli-<br>gations referred to in (b) above.</p>
<p>2. Within five years of notification of this Directive,<br>the Commission shall, after Consulting the Conuct<br>Committee, submit to the Council a report on the<br>application of Artides 3 and 5 and on such modifica-<br>tions as it would be possible to make thereto.</p>
<p>SECTION VI</p>
<p>Final provisions</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes shall bring into force the<br>measures necessary to comply with this Directive not<br>later than 30 June 1983. They shall forthwith inform<br>the Commission thereof.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes may postpone application of the<br>measures referred to in paragraph 1 until 36 months<br>from the date on which they bring such measures into<br>force.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;As from the notification of this Directive,<br>Member Sutes shall communicate to the Commission<br>the main provisions of the laws, regulations and<br>administrative provisions which they adopt in the field<br>governed by this Directive.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>This Directive is addressed to the Member Sutes.</p>
<p>Done at Brusscls, 15 February 1982.</p>
<p>For the Council</p>
<p>The President</p>

<p>COUNCIL DIRECTIVE<br></p>
<p>of 17 April 1989</p>
<p>coordinating the requirements for the drawing-up, scrutiny and distribution of the prospeetus<br>to be published when transferable securities are offered to the public<br></p>
<p>(89/298/EEC)</p>
<p>THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES.</p>
<p>Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community, and in partieular Artide 54<br>thereof.</p>
<p>Having regard to the proposal from the Commission ('),</p>
<p>In cooperation with the European Parliament (*),</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the Economic and Social<br>Committee (’),</p>
<p>Whereas investment in transferable securities. like any other<br>form of investment, involves risks; whereas the protection of<br>investors requires that they be put in a position to make a<br>correct assessment of such risks so as to be able to take<br>investment decisions in full knowledge of the faets;</p>
<p>Whereas the provision of full, appropnate information<br>conceming transferable securities and the issuers of such<br>securities promotes the protection of investors;</p>
<p>Whereas, moreover, such information is an effeetive means<br>of inereasing confidence m transferable securities and thus<br>contributes to the proper funetioning and development of<br>transferable securities markets;</p>
<p>Whereas a genuine Community information policy relating<br>to transferable securities should therefore be introduced;<br>whereas, by virtue of the safeguards that it offers investors<br>and its impaet on the proper funetioning of transferable<br>securities markets, such an information policy is capable of<br>promoting the interpenetration of national transferable<br>securities markets and thus encouraging the creation of a<br>genuine European Capital market;</p>
<p>Whereas Council Directive 80/390/EEC of 17 March 1980<br>coordinating the requirements for the drawing-up, scrutiny<br>and distribution of the listing partieulars to be published for<br>the admission of secunties to offidal stock exchange<br>listing (*), as last amended by Directive 87/345/EEC (’),<br>represents an important step in the implementation of such a</p>
<p>(') OJ No C 226. 31. 8. 1982. p. 4.</p>
<p>{') OJ No C 125, 17.5.1982, p. 176 and OJ No C 69.<br>20. 3. 1989.</p>
<p>(’) OJ No C 310. 30. 11. 1981. p. 50.</p>
<p>'•) OJ No L 100, 17. 4. 1980. p. 1.</p>
<p>’ OJ No L 185. 4. 7. 1987. p. 81.</p>
<p>Community information policy; whereas that Directive<br>coordinates the information to be published w hen securities<br>are admitted to stock exchange listing conceming the nature<br>of the securities offered and the issuers of such securities. so<br>as to enable investors to make an informed assessment of the<br>assets and Iiabilities, financial position, profits and losses and<br>prospeets of issuers and of the rights attaching to such<br>securities;</p>
<p>Whereas such an information policy also requires that when<br>transferable secunties are offered to the public for the first<br>time in a Member State, whether by, or on behalf of the issuer<br>or a third party, whether or not they are subsequentlv listed,<br>a prospeetus containing information of this nature must be<br>made available to investors; whereas it is also necessary to<br>coordinate the contents of that prospeetus in order to achieve<br>equivalence of the minimum safeguards afforded to investors<br>in the various Member States;</p>
<p>Whereas, so far, it has proved impossible to furnish .i<br>common definition of the term ‘public offer’ and all its<br>constituent parts;</p>
<p>Whereas, in cases where a public offer is of transferable<br>securities which are to be admitted to official listing on a<br>stock exchange, information similar to that required b\<br>Directive 80/390/EEC, whilst being adapted to the<br>circumstances of the public offer, must be supplied; w hereas.<br>for public offers of transferable securities that are not to bc<br>admitted to official stock exchange listing, less detailed<br>information can be required so as not to burden small and<br>medium-sized issuers unduly; whereas, for public offers ol<br>transferable securities that are to be admitted to official stock<br>exchange listing, the degree of coordination achieved is such<br>that a prospeetus approved by the competent authorities of a<br>Member State can be used for public offers of the same<br>securities in another Member State on the basis of mutual<br>recognition; whereas mutual recognition should also apply<br>where public offer prospeetuses comply with the basic<br>standards laid down in Directive 80/390/EEC and are<br>approved by the competent authorities even in the absence of<br>a request for admission to official stock exchange listing;</p>
<p>Whereas in order to ensure that the purposes of this Directive<br>will be fully realized it is necessary to inelude within the seope<br>of this Directive transferable securities issued by companies<br>or firms governed by the laws of third countries;</p>

<p>Whereas it is advisable to provide for the extension, by means<br>.»t agreements to be conduded by the Community with third<br>countries, of the recognition of prospeetuses from those<br>countries on a reciprocal basis:</p>
<p>HAS ADOPTED THIS DIRECTIVE:</p>
<p>SECTION I</p>
<p>General provisions</p>
<p>Article 1</p>
<p>I This Directive shall apply to transferable securities<br>\\ hich are offered to the public for the first time in a Member<br>State provided that these securities are not already listed on a<br>stock exchange situated or operating in that Member<br>State.</p>
<p>2. Where an offer to the public is for part only of the<br>transferable securities from a single issue, the Member States<br>need not require that another prospeetus be published if the<br>other part is subsequently offered to the public.</p>
<p>Article 2</p>
<p>This Directive shall not apply:</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;to the foliowing types of offer:</p>
<p>(a) where transferable secunties are offered to persons<br>in the context of their trades, professions or<br>occupations, and/or</p>
<p>(b) &nbsp;where transferable securities are offered to a<br>restricted circle of persons, and/or</p>
<p>(c) where the selling price of all the transferable<br>secunties offered does not exceed ECU 40 000,<br>and/or</p>
<p>(d) where the transferable secunties offered can be<br>acquired only for a consideration of at least ECU<br>40 000 per investor;</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;to transferable securities of the foliowing types:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;to transferable securities offered in individual<br>denominations of at least ECU 40 000;</p>
<p>(b) to units issued by collective investment undertakings<br>other than of the closed-end type;</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;to transferable securities issued by a State or by one<br>of a State‘s regional or local authorities or by public<br>intemational bodies of which one or more Member<br>States are members;</p>
<p><sup>z</sup>d) to transferable securities offered in connection with<br>a take-over bid;</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;to transferable securities offered in connection with<br>a merger;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;to shares allotted free of charge to the holders ol<br>shares;</p>
<p>(g) &nbsp;to shares or transferable securities equivalent to<br>shares offered in exchange for shares in the same<br>company if the offer of such new securities does not<br>involve anv overall inerease in the company s issued<br>shares Capital;</p>
<p>(h) to transferable securities offered by their employer<br>or by an affiliated undertaking to or for the benefit<br>of serving or former employees;</p>
<p>(i) &nbsp;to transferable securities resuiting from the<br>conversion of convertible debt securities or from the<br>exercise of the rights conferred by warrants or to<br>shares offered in exchange for exchangeable debt<br>securities, provided that a public offer prospeetus or<br>listing partieulars relating to those convertible or<br>exchangeable debt securities or those warrants were<br>published in the same Member State;</p>
<p>(j) &nbsp;to transferable securities issued, with a view to their<br>obtaining the means necessary to achieve their<br>disinterested objectives, by associations with legal<br>status or non-profit-making bodies, recognized by<br>the State;</p>
<p>(k) to shares or transferable securities equivalent to<br>shares, ownership of which entitles the holder to<br>avail himself of the services rendered by bodies such<br>as ‘building societies’, ‘Crédits popuiaires’.<br>‘Genossenschaftsbanken’, or ‘Industrial and<br>Provident Societies’, or to become a member of such<br>a body;</p>
<p>(l) &nbsp;to Euro-securities which are not the subject of a<br>generalized campaign of advertising or<br>canvassing.</p>
<p>Article J</p>
<p>For the purposes of this Directive:</p>
<p>(a) ‘collective investment undertakings other than of the<br>closed-end type’ shall mean unit trusts and investment<br>companies:</p>
<p>— the object of which is the collective investment of<br>Capital provided by the public, and which operate on<br>the principle of risk spreading, and</p>
<p>— the units of which are, at the holders’ request,<br>repurchased or redeemed, directly or indirectlv, out<br>of the assets of those undertakings. Action taken by<br>such undertakings to ensure that the stock exchange<br>value of their units does not significantly varv from<br>their net asset value shall be regarded as equivalent<br>to such repurchase or redemption;</p>
<p>(b) ‘units of a collective investment undertaking’ shall mean<br>transferable secunties issued by a collective investment<br>undertaking representing the rights of the participants in<br>such an undertaking over its assets;</p>
<p>538</p>
<p>Prop. 1991/92:113</p>
<p>Bilaga 16</p>
<p>No L 124/10</p>
<p>Official Journal of the European Communities</p>
<p>5. 5. HM</p>
<p>(c) &nbsp;‘issuers' shall mean companies and other legal persons<br>and any undertakings the transferable securities of<br>which are offered to the public;</p>
<p>(d) ‘eredit institution’ shall mean an undertaking the<br>business of which is to receive deposits or other<br>repayable funds from the public and to grant eredits for<br>its own account. ineluding eredit institutions such as<br>referred to in Article 2 of Directive 77/780/EEC (’), as<br>last amended by Directive 86/524/EEC (<sup>2</sup>);</p>
<p>(e) &nbsp;‘transferable securities’ shall mean shares in companies<br>and other transferable secunties equivalent to shares in<br>companies. debt securities having a maturiry of at least<br>one year and other transferable securities equivalent to<br>debt securities, and any other transferable securiry<br>giving the right to acquire any such transferable<br>securities by subscription or exchange;</p>
<p>(f) &nbsp;‘Euro-securities’ shall mean transferable securities<br>which:</p>
<p>— are to be underwrinen and distributed by a syndicate<br>at least two of the members of which have their<br>registered offices in different States, and</p>
<p>— are offered on a significant scale in one or more<br>States other than that of the issuers registered office,<br>and</p>
<p>— may be subscribed for or initially acquired only<br>through a eredit institution or other financial<br>institution.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>Member States shall ensure that any offer of transferable<br>secunties to the public within their temtories is subject to the<br>publication of a prospeetus by the person making the<br>offer.</p>
<p>Article 5</p>
<p>Member States may provide for partial or complete<br>exemption from the obligation to publish a prospeetus where<br>the transferable securities being offered to the public are:</p>
<p>(a) &nbsp;debt securities orothertransferablesecuritiesequivalent<br>to debt securities issued in a continuous or repeated<br>manner by eredit institutions or other financial<br>institutions equivalent to eredit institutions which<br>regularly publish their annual accounts and which,<br>within the Community, are set up or governed by a<br>special law or pursuant to such a law, or are subject to<br>public supervision intended to protect savings;</p>
<p>(b) debt securities orothertransferable securities equivalent<br>to debt securities issued by companies and other legal<br>persons which are nationals of a Member State and<br>which:</p>

<p>— in carrying on their business, benefit from State<br>monopolies, and</p>
<p>— are set up or governed by a special law or pursuant to<br>such a law or whose borrowings are unconditionaik<br>and irrevocably guaranteed by a Member State or<br>one of a Member State’s regional or local<br>authorities;</p>
<p>(c) debt securities issued by legal persons, other than<br>companies, which are nationals of a Member State,<br>and</p>
<p>— were set up by special law, and</p>

<p>Article 6</p>
<p>If a full prospeetus has been published in a Member State<br>within the previous 12 months, the foliowing prospeetus<br>drawn up by the same issuer in the same State, but relating to<br>different transferable securities, may indicate only those<br>changes likely to influence the value of the securities which<br>have occurred since publication of the full prospeetus.</p>

<p>COUNCIL DIRECTIVE<br>of 12 December 1988<br>on the information to be published when a major holding in a listed company is<br>acquired or disposed of<br></p>
<p>(88/627/EEC)</p>
<p>THE COUNCIL OF THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES,</p>
<p>Having regard to the Treaty establishing the European<br>Economic Community, and in partieular Article 54<br>thereof.</p>
<p>Having regard to the proposal from the Commission ('),</p>
<p>In cooperation with the European Parliament f),</p>
<p>Having regard to the opinion of the Economic and Social<br>Committee (0.</p>
<p>Whereas a policy of adequate information of investors in<br>the field of transferable secunties is likely to improve<br>investor protection, to inerease investors' confidence in<br>securities markets and thus to ensure that securities<br>markets funetion correctly;</p>
<p>Whereas, by making such protection more equivalent,<br>coordination of that policy at Community ievel is likely<br>to make for greater inter*penetrarion of the Member<br>States’ transferable securities markets and therefore help<br>to establish a true European Capital market;</p>
<p>Whereas to that end investors should be informed of<br>major holdings and of changes in those holdings in<br>Community companies the shares of which are officially<br>listed on stock exchanges situtated or operating within<br>the Community;</p>
<p>Whereas coordinated ruies should be laid dovm<br>conceming the detailed content and the procedure for<br>applying that requirement;</p>
<p>Whereas companies, the shares of which are officially<br>listed on a Community stock exchange, can inform the<br>public of changes in major holdings only if they have<br>been informed of such changes by the holden of those<br>holdings;</p>
<p>Whereas most Member States do not subject holders to<br>such a requirement and where such a requirement exists<br>there are appreciable differences in the procedures for</p>
<p>C) OJ No C 351, 31. 12. IMS. p. 35, and<br>OJ No C 255, 25. 9. 1917. p. 6.</p>
<p>0 OJ No C 125, 11. 5. 1M7, p. 144, and<br>OJ No C 309, 5. 12. 19U.</p>
<p>f) OJ No C 263, 20. 10. 1986, p. I.<br></p>
<p>applying it; whereas coordinated ruies should therefore<br>be adopted at Community level in this field,</p>
<p>HAS ADOPTED THIS DIRECTIVE:</p>
<p>Articlt 1</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall make subject to this Directive<br>natural persons and legal entities in public or private law<br>who acquire or dispose of, directly or through interme-<br>diaries, holdings meeting the criteria laid dovm in Article<br>4 (1) which involve changes in the holdings of voting<br>rights in companies incorporated under their law the<br>ahares of which are officially listed on a stock exchange or<br>exchanges situated or operating within one or more<br>Member States.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where the acquisidon or disposal of a major holding<br>such as referred to in paragraph 1 is effeeted by means of<br>certificates representing shares, this Directive shall apply<br>to the bearers of those certificates, and not to the issuer.</p>
<p>X This Directive shall not apply to the acquisition or<br>disposal of major holdings in collective investment<br>undertakings.</p>
<p>4. Paragraph 5 (c) of Schedule C of the Annex to<br>Council Directive 79/279/EEC of 5 March 1979 coordi-<br>nating the conditions for the admission of securities to<br>official stock exchange listing (*)» as last amended by<br>Directive 82/148/EECfX is hereby replaced by the<br>foliowing:</p>
<p>*(c) The company must inform the public of any<br>changes in the strueture (shareholders and<br>breakdovms of holdings) of the major holdings in<br>its Capital as compared with information<br>previously published on that subject as soon as<br>such changes come to its notice.</p>
<p>In partieular, a company which is not subject to<br>Council Directive 88/627/EEC of 12 December<br>1988 on the information to be published when a<br>major holding in a listed company is acquired or<br>disposed of Q must inform the public within nine<br>calender days whenever it comes to its notice that<br>a person or entity has acquired or disposed of a<br>number of shares such that his or its holding<br>exceeds or falls below one of the thresholds laid<br>dovm in Article 4 of that Directive.</p>

<p>Article 2</p>
<p>For the purposes of Directive, ‘acquiring a holding* shall<br>mean not only purchasing a holding, but also acquisition<br>by any other means whatsoever, including acquisition in<br>one of the situations refened to in Article 7.<br></p>

<p>Article 3</p>
<p>Member States may subject the natural persons, legal<br>entities and companies refened to in Article 1 (1) to<br>requirements stricter than those provided for in this<br>Directive or to additional requirements, provided that<br>such requirements apply generally to all those acquiring<br>or disposing of holdings and ali companies or to all those<br>falling within a partieular category acquiring or disposing<br>of holdings or of companies.</p>
<p>Article 4</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Where a natural person or legal entity refened to.in<br>Article l (1) acquires or disposes of a holding in a<br>company referred to in Article I (1) and where, foliowing<br>that acquisition or disposal, the proportion of voting<br>nghts held by that person or legal entity reaches, exceeds<br>or falls below one of the thresholds of 10*/», 20 */•,'/&gt;<br>50 •/• and ¥„ he shall notify the company and at the same<br>time the competent authority or authorities refened to in<br>Article 13 within seven calendar days of the proportion of<br>voting rights he holds foliowing that acquisition or<br>disposal. <p>The period of seven calendar days shall start from the<br>time when the owner of the major holding leams of the<br>acquisition or disposal, or from the time when, in view of<br>the circumstances, he should have leamt of it</p>
<p>Member States may further provide that a company must<br>also bc informed in respect of the proportion of Capital<br>held by a natural person or legal entity.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member States shall, if necessary, establish in their<br>national law, and determine in accordance with it, the<br>manner in which the voting rights to be taken into<br>account for the purposes of applying paragraph 1 are to<br>be brought to the notice of the natural persons and legal<br>entities referred to in Article I (1).</p>
<p>Artide 3</p>

<p>Within one month of that general meeting, the public<br>shall be informed of all holdings of 10 % or more in<br>accordance with Article 10.</p>
<p>Article 6</p>
<p>If the person or entity acquiring or disposing of a major<br>holding as defined in Article 4 is a member of a group of<br>undertakings required under Directive 83/349/EEC (*) to<br>draw up Consolidated accounts, that person or entity shall<br>be exempt from the obligation to make the deciaration<br>provided for in Article 4 (1) and in Article 5 if it is made<br>by the parent undertaking or, where the parent<br>undertaking is itself a subsidiary undertaking, by its own<br>parent undertaking.</p>
<p>Article 7</p>
<p>For the purposes of determining whether a natural person<br>or legal entity as referred to in Article 1 (1) is required to<br>make a deciaration as provided for in Article 4 (1) and in<br>Article 5, the foliowing shall be regarded as voting rights<br>held by that person or entity:</p>
<p>— voting rights held by other persons or entities in their<br>own names but on behalf of that person or entity,</p>
<p>— voting rights held by an undertaking controlled by<br>that person or entity;</p>
<p>— voting rights held by a third party with whom that<br>person or entity has conduded a written agreement<br>which obliges them to adopt, by concerted exercise of<br>the voting rights they hold, a lasting common policy<br>towards the management of the company in question.</p>
<p>— voting rights held by a third party under a written<br>agreement conduded with that person or entity or<br>with an undertaking controlled by that person or<br>entity providing for the temporary transfer for<br>consideration of the voting rights in question,</p>
<p>— voting rights attaching to shares owned by that person<br>or entity which are lodged as »ecurity, except where<br>the person or entity holding the security Controls the<br>voting rights and declares his intention of exercising<br>them, in which case they shall be regarded as the<br>latters voting rights,</p>
<p>— voting rights attaching to shares of which that person<br>or entity has the life interest.</p>

<p>Article 8</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purposes of this Directive, ‘controlled<br>undertaking' shall mean any undertaking in which a<br>natural person or legal entity:</p>
<p>(a) has a majority of the sahreholders' or members* voting<br>rights; or</p>
<p>(b) has the right to appoint or remove a majority of the<br>members of the administrative, management or<br>supervisory body and is at the same time a<br>shareholder in, or member of, the undertaking in<br>question; or</p>
<p>(c) is a shareholder or member and alone Controls a<br>majority of the shareholders* or memben* voting<br>rights pursuant to an agreement entered into with<br>other shareholders or members of the undertaking.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;For the purposes of paragraph 1. a parent<br>undertaking’* rights as regards voting, appointment and<br>removal shall inelude the rights of any other controlled<br>undertaking and those of any person or entity acting in<br>his own name but on behalf of the parent undertaking or<br>of any other controlled undertaking.</p>
<p>Article 9</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities may exempt from the<br>deciaration provided for in Article 4 (1) the acquisition or<br>disposal of a major holding, as defined in Article 4, by a<br>professional dealer in securities, in so far as that<br>acquisition or disposal is effected in his capacity as a<br>professional dealer in securities and in ao far as the<br>acquisition is not used by the dealer to intervene in the<br>management of the company concemed.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities shall require the profes-<br>sional dealers in securities referred to in paragraph 1 to be<br>memben of a stock exchange situated or operating within<br>a Member State or to be approved or supervised by a<br>competent authorir' such as referred to in Article 12.</p>
<p>Article 10</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;A company which has received a deciaration referred<br>to in the first subparagraph of Article 4 (I) must in turn<br>disclose it to the public in each of the Member States in<br>which its shares are officially listed on a stock exchange<br>as soon as possible but not more than nine calender days<br>after the receipt of that deciaration.</p>
<p>A Member State may provide for the disciosure to the<br>public, referred to in the fint subparagraph, to be made<br>not by the company concemed but by the competent<br>authority, possibly in cooperation with that company.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;The disciosure referred to in paragraph 1 must be<br>made by publication in one or more newspapers<br>distributed throughout or widely in the Member State or<br>States concemed or be made available to the public either<br>in writing in places indicated by announcements to be<br>published in one or more newspapen distributed<br>throughout or widely in the Member State or States<br>concemed or by other equivalent means approved by the<br>competent authorities.</p>
<p>The said disciosure must be made by publication in the<br>official language or languages, or in one of the official<br>languages or in another language, provided that in the<br>Member State in question the official language or<br>languages or such other language is or are customary in<br>the sphere of finance and accepted by the competent<br>authorities.</p>
<p>Article 11</p>
<p>The competent authorities may, exceptionally, exempt the<br>companies referred to in Article 1 (1) from the obligation<br>to notify the public set out in Article 10 where those<br>authorities consider that the disciosure of such<br>information would be contrary to the public interest or<br>seriously detrimental to the companies concemed.<br>provides that, in the latter case, such omission would not<br>be likely to mislead the public with regard to the faets<br>and circumstances knowledge of which is essential for the<br>assessment of the transferable securities in question.</p>
<p>Article 12</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes shall designate the competent<br>authority or authorities for the purposes of this Directive<br>and shall inform the Commission accordingly, specifying,<br>where appropriate, and division of duties between those<br>authorities.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes shall ensure that the competent<br>authorities have such powers as may be necessary for the<br>performance of their duties.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;The competent authorities in the Member Sutes<br>shall cooperate wherever necessary for the purpose of<br>performing their duties and shall exchange any<br>information useful for that purpose.</p>
<p>Article 13</p>
<p>For the purpose of this Directive, the competent<br>authorities shall be those of the Member State the law of<br>which govems the companies referred to in Article 1 (1).</p>

<p>Articlt 14</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Statea shall provide that every person who<br>c a mes on or has carried on an activity in the employment<br>of a competent authority whall be bound by professional<br>secrecy. This means that no confidentiai information<br>received in the course of their duties may be divulged to<br>any person or authority except by virtue of provisions laid<br>down by law.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Paragraph 1 shall not, however, preclude the<br>competent authorities of the various Member States from<br>exchanging information as provided for in this Directive.<br>Information thus exchanged shall bc covered by the<br>obligation of professional secrecy to which persons<br>employed or previously employed by the competent<br>authorities receiving the information are subject.</p>
<p>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;A competent authority which receives confidentiai<br>information pursuant to paragraph 2 may use it solely for<br>the periormancc of its duties.</p>
<p>Articlt 15</p>
<p>Member States shall provide for appropriate sanctions in<br>cases where the natural persons or legal entities and the<br>companies referred to in Article i (1) do not comply with<br>the provisions of this Directive.</p>
<p>(a) to permit regular consulutions on any practicai<br>problems which arise from the application of this<br>Directive and on which exchanges of view are deemed<br>useful;</p>
<p>(b) to facilitate consultations between the Member Sutes<br>on the stricter or additional requirements which they<br>may lay down in accordance with Artide 3, so that the<br>requirements imposed in all the Member Sutes may<br>be brought into iine, in accordance with Article 54 (3)<br>(g) of the Treaty;</p>
<p>(c) to advise the Commission, if necessary, on any<br>additions or amendmcnts to be made to this Directive.</p>
<p>Articlt 17</p>
<p>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes shall uke the measures necessary for<br>them to comply with this Directive before 1 January<br>1991. They shall forthwith inform the Commission<br>thereof.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;Member Sutes shall communicate to the<br>Commission the provisions of national law whidh they<br>adopt in the field governed by this Directive.</p>
<p>Articlt 18</p>
<p>This Directive is addressed to the Member Sutes.</p>
<p>Done at Brussels, 12 December 1988.</p>
